Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Eruption Dynamics From Low-Frequency Volcano-Seismic Signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a CAREER award supported by the Petrology and Geochemistry, Geophysics, and Education and Human Resources programs from the Division of Earth Sciences in cooperation with the Americas Program of the Office of International Sciences and Engineering. This proposed CAREER research and education project is focused on advancing our understanding of eruption dynamics using novel seismological modeling and data-acquisition approaches and by tasking middle-school and undergraduate students, working in conjunction with graduate students, into the data acquisition aspects of the research. The principal objectives of this study and professional goals of the PI are to: 1) accelerate the adaptation of advanced seismological source modeling by researchers and monitoring networks through improving model verification and statistical analysis; 2) train a new generation of volcano seismologists who are not only proficient with fundamental seismological theory and tools, but also adept at using diverse multidisciplinary data to guide models of volcano-seismic signals; and 3) promote quantitative skills and the use of interdisciplinary data to solve problems.

Intellectual Merit: Seismological recordings of volcanic processes are both the most abundant and the most widely data sets used by volcano monitoring agencies for real-time assessment of the volcanic hazard. But, except for only a very few cases, seismic data are underused. Advanced waveform-modeling tools have been available for decades and are in use by only a small group of volcano seismologists because of some specific challenges. The use of waveform modeling will benefit from comprehensively and systematically exploring the effects of small-scale structure and attenuation on synthetic Green?s functions and source inversions derived from them. The investigator will build on his recent experience in monitoring open-vent volcanic processes in Guatemala (Fuego and Santiaguito) that indicate that coupling measurements of tilt along with broadband seismic data allows for determining the effect tilt, especially on very-long-period waveforms. Moreover, simultaneously collecting infrasound data and monitoring SO2 emissions for will allow for joint interpretations of multiple data sets that have not been possible before. Ultimately this work will push waveform modeling of volcano seismic signals into wider use.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research advancements will be made in conjunction with educational activities that will enhance the teaching and learning skills of a spectrum of students involved in this work, ranging from middle-school science students, undergraduates and Ph.D. and M.S. students. This work will promote increased interdisciplinary volcanological knowledge, especially among graduate students and foster the use of quantitative data in eighth grade Earth science curricula at 6 schools. This project will use active recruitment and mentoring activities to enhance the participation of minority undergraduate students in both volcano seismology and earthquake seismology research. This work will also enhance the hazard mitigation capacity of developing countries. The scientific advances will influence not only volcano seismology, but also the field of earthquake seismology, where some of the same obstacles to source modeling exist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismological recordings of volcanic processes are both the most abundant and the most widely used by volcano monitoring agencies for real-time assessment of the volcanic hazard. While earthquakes commonly occur within and near volcanoes, a variety of other volcanic processes produce seismic waves as well. Magma, which contains solid, liquid, and gas components, does not always move smoothly from depth to the surface. The acceleration of magma through a complex pathway through the surface can produce seismic signals that are very different from earthquake signals. A variety of other processes, such as gas moving through cracks and bubbles bursting at the magma surface, produce seismic signals as well. Thus, seismic recordings of these processes provide a view into the state of the volcano that is critical to hazard mitigation.

While seismic data is abundant, in many cases, the processes involved in generating them are not well understood. One of the key aims of this project was to improve the use of seismological methods for advanced analysis. These tools can be used in research and ultimately, incorporated into real-time monitoring. The two general areas where this has been achieved are: 1) through new statistical tools for evaluating models of seismic sources and 2) through the incorporation of other data types into interpretations of physical processes.

High quality data from active volcanoes was required to achieve the project goals. Data from two volcanoes in Guatemala (Fuego and Pacaya) were collected in a number of field campaigns. These volcanoes were chosen because they are persistently active, relatively accessible, and each has a different style. Fuego has small explosive eruptions 10 or more times per day, each of which produce rich data. Pacaya often has an open lava surface within the conduit that bubbles to produce a constant plume of gas. These gasses are exsolved from the magma as it convects in the upper conduit. Fuego sits at the south end of a long ridge that allows for data collection from relatively close proximity to the summit vent. Pacaya is passive enough to permit installation of monitoring equipment at the summit. Together, these volcanoes provided excellent data for this study.

Using the data from these volcanoes, we developed a modeling approach that allows for a more reliable understanding of model uncertainty, which is important for interpreting the model in terms of volcanic process. The method uses a nonlinear approach to explore the entire space of possible models. This approach can also incorporate signals that may be recorded by a seismic station, but that it was not designed to record: ground rotation. At relatively close distances to the volcanic vent, the ground can tilt as the volcano inflates or deflates and at certain timescales, this can interfere with the up-down or side-to-side motion a seismometer is designed to record. But rather than a source of error, in this study we have shown that ground rotation can actually be used to improve the models.

The interpretation of seismic models was also improved in this study by incorporating additional data sources. Because volcanic eruptions involve the transfer of mass into the atmosphere, instruments sensitive to these types of emissions are especially valuable. We employed low-frequency sound (infrasound), thermal imaging, and gas emission monitoring. Volcanic sulfur dioxide can be detected in low concentrations and is a good proxy for total gas emission. Recent advances in sulfur dioxide emission measurements have enabled measurement on time scales that compare with seismic data. At Fuego, we found that some types of seismic events correlate well with gas emission, including seismic tremor and small explosive events. The joint interpretation of the latter, for example, demonstrates that the vent seals slowly prior to each small explosion. The joint interpretation of infrasound and seismic data at Pacaya show that up to half of the seismic signal recorded as background tremor is simply due to small bubbles bursting at the surface of the lava lake.

The research advancements were made in conjunction with educational activities that enhanced the teaching and learning skills of a spectrum of students involved in this work, from middle-school science students through to undergraduate, M.S., and Ph.D. students. Partnerships with area schools have fostered the use of quantitative data in eighth grade Earth science classes. Each summer, one or two undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented minorities engaged in volcano-seismic research. And M.S. and Ph.D. students were trained in interdisciplinary quantitative volcanological skills required for the next advances in research. The scientific advances will influence not only volcano seismology, but also the field of earthquake seismology, where some of the same obstacles to source modeling exist.
